Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Distances to high-velocity clouds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative award will fund continuation of a project to measure distances to the Galactic high velocity clouds (HVCs), massive clouds of neutral hydrogen gas moving at velocities incompatible with a simple model of differential galactic rotation. Since they stand out from the gas in the Galactic Disk, they can be used as test particles for energetic phenomena in the Milky Way. The program will study HVC metallicities and distances using interstellar absorption lines in the spectra of stars projected against the clouds. The results of this project will be important for estimates of several fundamental parameters of Galactic evolution, including the rate of infall of low metallicity gas, the potential of the dark matter halo, the rate of circulation of gas between Disk and Halo, and the fraction of ionizing photons escaping the Disk.

The Broader Impacts of this program include training of graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our Galaxy contains about 100 billion stars, most of which are concentrated in a thin plane about 100,000 light years across and 3,000 light years thick - the Galactic Disk. These stars rotate around the Galactic Center in nearly circular orbits. Another 10 billion stars form the Galactic Halo, a huge spherical envelope that surrounds the Disk. Between the stars lie gas and dust, forming the interstellar medium (ISM). Most of the ISM moves in nearly circular orbits around the Galactic Center and is even more strongly concentrated to a plane than the stars.

The ISM can be detected in several ways. In particular, cool gas emits in the 21-cm line of neutral hydrogen. All-sky 21-cm maps show that up to about 10% of the ISM lies out of the plane and has velocities deviating from rotation by up to 450 km/s. These are the "high-velocity clouds" or HVCs. The high velocities of these objects mean that they contain a significant fraction of the kinetic energy of the gas in our Galaxy.

The key to understanding these objects comes from measurements of their distances and the concentration of heavy elements ("metallicity"). The conclusion from many studies is that some clouds have low metallicity are located in the inner Galactic Halo; these are likely gas newly accreting onto the Milky Way. Some clouds have metallicity similar to that of stars in the Magellanic Clouds and are very distant; these are likely the result of tidal stripping of the Magellanic Clouds. Some clouds have near-solar metallicity and are close to the Galactic Disk; these clouds originate from the
churning of the gas in the Disk due to supernovae, as part of a "Galactic Fountain". The accreting low-metallicity gas clouds provide strong evidence that the Milky Way is still forming - new gas enters the Milky Way at a rate similar to the rate of star formation, where the derived value of rate of accretion is based mostly on the cloud distances that we derived.

These conclusions depend heavily on the results of our program to determine cloud distances. The principal method to find the distances to the HVCs consists of searching for interstellar absorption in the spectrum of suitable stars with known distances. Stars behind the cloud will show absorption, while stars in front do not, bracketing the cloud distance (see Figure 1). In practice, this method requires data from many different telescopes (in the we used data from 10 different telescopes).

To find suitable stars, we defined a sample of about 300,000 suitable candidate stars, based on the HK survey, the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), and the 2MASS survey (Two micron All Sky Survey).
For 2500 stars from the SDSS dataset we have photometry,although some of it is saturated. As, the near-infrared colors of the 2MASS stars are insufficient to confirm their type, we ran a 200-night program at the WIYN 0.9m telescope between 2009 and 2014 to obtain UBV photometry for ~150 our stars. For about 500 SDSS stars, we also have an intermediate-resolution (1 Angstrom) spectrum available. Between 2003 and 2009, we obtained about 108 nights of observing time at the APO observatory, to take ~700 additional spectra, giving us a sample of ~1200 stars with spectra.

To determine the distances to these stars, we developed new methods to model the stellar atmospheres and compare the predicted colors and stellar absorption lines, using Bayesian statistics to find the most likely combination of effective temperature, gravity and stellar metallicity.
